com.devwebsphere.wxsutils.bloom
Class CountingBloomFilter

java.lang.Object
  com.devwebsphere.wxsutils.bloom.CountingBloomFilter
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public final class CountingBloomFilter
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

This is a classic Bloom Filter. This is a probabilistic data structure which can be used to check if an item is definitely in a 'list' and also check if an item is probably not in the list. It's implemented as a bit array whose size depends on the expected number of entries and the required probability of false positive in the not in the list case.

Author:
bnewport
See Also:

Constructor Detail

CountingBloomFilter

public CountingBloomFilter(int numExpectedEntries,
                           int numPhases,
                           double saturation)
Construct a filter which is expected to hold a certain number of entries with a K way hash

Parameters:
numExpectedEntries - The number of entries expected
numPhases - The number of hashes to apply to keys
saturation - The percentage of bits that are one when fully populated (0.5 is good)

CountingBloomFilter

public CountingBloomFilter(int numExpectedEntries)
The default constructor, just takes the number of expected entries.

Method Detail

getExpectedFalsePositive

public final double getExpectedFalsePositive()
This is the probability that a key that really isn't present is returned as present, the false positive rate. More phases and lower saturation settings should lower this.

Returns:

add

public void add(byte[] key)
This adds a new key to the bloom filter, if the key isn't a byte[] then it must be converted to one.

Parameters:
key -

contains

public boolean contains(byte[] key)
This checks if a key is present using the filter. This can return true for keys not in the filter with the probability of the expectedFalsePositive rate.

getDigest

public static java.security.MessageDigest getDigest()
This just returns the digest we will use to generate hashes. SHA and MD5 are very good hash functions. MD5 is about 40% faster than SHA so we'll use MD5

Returns:
